newsitem.title: FRANCE: French comments on ECB very worrying-Poehl.
newsitem.headline: French comments on ECB very worrying-Poehl.

text.p: Former Bundesbank head Karl Otto Poehl said on Tuesday that French calls for a political authority to counterbalance the future European Central Bank (ECB) were "extremely worrying."
"The European Central Bank is the centrepiece, the cornerstone of Economic and Monetary Union," he told a conference on Europe's planned single currency, the euro.
"For Germany, it was a basic condition to have an institution as independent as the Bundesbank," he added.
"The fact that the highest French representatives, if I understood what I read, ask for control. That is something which puts the whole concept into question."
France wants a council to coordinate economic and exchange rate policies in the euro zone after the its launch in 1999 and counterbalance the ECB's role in fixing monetary policy.
It also says Europe should use the launch of the euro to fight against any competitive devaluation in the dollar.

"Our German friends say they do not want a 'soft euro'. Neither do I. Neither a soft euro, nor soft economic growth," French Prime Minister Alain Juppe wrote in a book published last month. "I insist that these questions must not be left to the judgment of central bank governors alone."
Poehl, who left the Bundesbank in 1991 after nine years as president and is now a director of private bank Sal Oppenheim, was involved in talks on monetary union in the 1980s.
He said there had always been differences between France and Germany on monetary and exchange rate policies.
"As far as exchange rate policy is concerned, I think there is a misunderstanding," he said.
During early talks, France wanted a clear exchange rate policy, while Germany had said this should be left to markets.
The compromise was that governments would decide on major changes to the exchange rate system -- for example a return to fixed exchange rates worldwide, he said.
"The day-to-day operation of the exchange rate system is the subject of the central bank, not the governments," he said.
If governments wanted the ECB to pursue a particular policy towards the dollar, it would ruin monetary policy and start a trade war with the Americans, who would never accept it, he added.
Moreover, the Maastricht treaty enshrined the independence of the central bank by forbidding its governors from taking instructions from politicians.
"The central bank is not allowed to accept instructions, neither from governments nor from parliaments, nor the councils of the central bank," he added.
The ECB governing council will comprise its president, vice-president and four executive members and the governors of national central banks.
Poehl also warned that calls by French officials for a appreciation of the dollar against the euro would undermine the credibility of the single currency from the start.

If you were an investor outside Europe with huge holdings in marks, knowing these would be swapped into euros in 1999 "and you are told by high officials in France that this currency should be devalued, you would immediately start to sell." Such investors would sell marks even before the euro existed.
"I don't know whether the recent weakness of the mark is an indication this process is already underway. I don't think so, but it could easily happen," he said.
Poehl, however, acknowledged a lack of democratic control on the ECB.

"This institution will be very powerful. You can argue this is not very democratic, but as long as it is efficient, as long as it provides us with a strong and stable European currency, I would overlook that," he said.
-- Myra MacDonald Paris Newsroom +33 1 42 21 53 81
